title: Collection agency contacting me for not paying up shoplifting debt
question: In November 2009, I made a huge mistake and was caught shoplifting at a large fashion retail store. I stole about $120 worth of clothing and ever since then, I have received many civil demand letters wanting $475 from me, which is ridiculous. I decided to ignore all of them and today I received a letter from a collection agency saying that the creditor will turn my name over to a licensed collection agency and this could harm my credit if I don't pay up what I owe.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Criminal defense,Criminal charges for theft,Lawsuits and disputes,Shoplifting
answers:
Unless you made some sort of agreement to pay them, there is nothing to turn over to a collection agency. You're correct that they would need some sort of legal ruling that you owed them money.

I doubt that any collection agency would be stupid enough to accept this referral... but if they were, I think it would be a serious violation of Federal debt collection law.

I usually don't invite people on Avvo to contact me directly, unless their case is in a county where I actually practice, but I'd really like to see this letter. Please contact my office during normal business hours (M-F 8:30-noon and M-Th 1:00-5:00) to get my fax number or another way to send it to us.

Please understand that this is a general discussion of legal principles by a California lawyer and does not create an attorney/client relationship. It's impossible to give detailed, accurate advice based on a few sentences on a website (and you shouldn't provide too much specific information about your legal matter on a public forum like this, anyway). You should always seek advice from an attorney licensed in your jurisdiction who can give you an informed opinion after reviewing all of the relevant information.

Debt collectors report all sorts of debts to the credit reporting agencies. You have the right to dispute that debt and to dispute the information reported, if you have proof that it is inaccurate or false. Below is a link to free sample letters on my web site that you can use to dispute credit reporting errors, such as sample letter #3.1.

The problem for you is that the theft is not an extension of credit or an ordinary bill or credit relationship, so the protections under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act do not apply to this situation, so sample letter numbers 1.1 or 1.2 probably will have no affect on this problem.

I am not sure that I would advise ignoring a debt collection letter, but I am also not sure how best to respond, given your unique circumstances.

It's a scare tactic. No one is likely to sue you for $475 for one of these civil demands, and no one can report you to a credit bureau without suing you and getting a judgment.
